revisions.rev: {{primary sources|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox software | name = PackageKit | logo = [[File:packagekit.png]] | screenshot = [[File:PackageKit on Fedora.png|300px]] | caption = ''gnome-packagekit'', a front-end for PackageKit, running on [[Fedora (operating system)|Fedora]] | collapsible = | author = | developer = Richard Hughes | released = | frequently updated = Yes | programming language = [[C (programming language)|C]], [[C++]], [[Python (programming language)|Python]] | operating system = [[Linux]] | platform = | size = | language = | status = Active | genre = [[Package management system]] | license = [[GNU General Public License]] | website = [http://www.packagekit.org/ www.packagekit.org] }} '''PackageKit''' is an [[open source]] and free suite of [[software application]]s designed to provide a consistent and high-level [[front end]] for a number of different [[package management system]]s. PackageKit was created by Richard Hughes. The suite is ostensibly [[cross-platform]], though it is primarily targeted at [[Linux distribution]]s which follow the interoperability standards set out by the [[freedesktop.org]] group. It uses the [[software libraries]] provided by the [[D-Bus]] and [[PolicyKit]] projects to handle [[inter-process communication]] and [[computer privilege]] negotiation. ==History== PackageKit was created by Richard Hughes and first proposed in a series of [[blog]] posts in 2007{{cite web |title=Installing and Updating Software Blows Goats |url=http://blogs.gnome.org/hughsie/2007/07/27/installing-and-updating-software-blows-goats/ |publisher=Richard Hughes |accessdate=18 January 2011}}{{cite web |title=Robert Hughes' blog posts about PackageKit |url=http://blogs.gnome.org/hughsie/?s=PackageKit |publisher=Richard Hughes |accessdate=18 January 2011}}, and is now developed by a small team of developers. [[Fedora (operating system)|Fedora]] 9 was the first operating system to use it as default front end for [[Yellow dog Updater, Modified|yum]]. It has undergone many updates in Fedora 10 and Fedora 11. ==Design== [[Image:Kpackagekit.png|thumb|250px|''KPackageKit'', the [[KDE]]-based front-end, integrates directly with KDE's System Settings modules. It is now called Apper as of 0.64+.{{cite web |url=http://polishlinux.org/kde/kpackagekit-interview/ |title=KpackageKit: future of package managers on your desktop |publisher=polishlinux.org |accessdate=10 July 2009}}]] PackageKit itself is a system activated [[daemon (computer software)|daemon]] called packagekitd, that abstracts out differences between the different systems. A library called libpackagekit also allows other programs to interact with PackageKit.{{cite web |title=PackageKit Reference Manual |url=http://www.packagekit.org/gtk-doc/PkClient.html |publisher=packagekit.org |accessdate=10 July 2009}} Features include: * Installing local files, ServicePack media and from remote sources. * Authorization using [[PolicyKit]]. * Does not replace existing packaging tools. * Multi-user system aware â will not allow shutdown in critical parts of the transaction. * A system activated daemon so exits when not in use. ===Front-ends=== There are three [[front-end]]s for PackageKit: * '''gnome-packagekit''' to be used in the [[GNOME]] desktop. * '''[[Apper]]''' to be used in the [[KDE]] desktop. * '''pkcon''' to be used on the [[command line]]. ===Back-ends=== A number of different [[package management system]]s (known as back-ends) support different abstract methods and signals that are used by the front-end tools.{{cite web
